speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The dawn is replacing night, and I must fill my willow basket with both poisonous and medicinal plants. The earth is both a womb and a tomb, producing many different plants, each with its own virtues. Nothing is so evil that it does not give some good to the earth, and nothing so good that it cannot be abused. Virtue becomes vice if misused, and vice can be dignified by proper use. This flower contains both poison and medicine: smelling it revives, tasting it kills. Similarly, humans have grace and base desire; if the worse prevails, death destroys them.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Bless you! Who greets me so sweetly so early? Young man, it suggests a troubled mind to say good morning so early instead of sleeping. Old men have care in their eyes and cannot sleep, but youth with clear minds should sleep soundly. Your early rising tells me you are disturbed, or else you haven't been to bed tonight.

speaker: ROMEO
content: The last part is true; I had a sweeter rest.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: God forgive sin. Were you with Rosaline?

speaker: ROMEO
content: With Rosaline, my spiritual father? No, I have forgotten that name and its sorrow.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: That's my good son. But where have you been then?

speaker: ROMEO
content: I'll tell you before you ask again. I have been feasting with my enemy, where suddenly someone wounded me who is also wounded by me. Our cures lie in your help and holy medicine. I bear no hatred, for my plea also helps my foe.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Be plain, good son, and straightforward in your meaning; a puzzling confession gets only a puzzling absolution.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Then know plainly that my heart's dear love is set on the fair daughter of rich Capulet. She loves me as I love her, and all is settled except what you must join in holy marriage. I'll tell you the details later, but I beg you to consent to marry us today.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Holy Saint Francis! What a change is this! Is Rosaline, whom you loved so dearly, so quickly abandoned? Young men's love lies not in their hearts but in their eyes. Jesus Mary, how much salt water washed your pale cheeks for Rosaline! How much salt water wasted to season a love that had no taste. The sun hasn't yet cleared your sighs from heaven, your old groans still ring in my old ears. Here on your cheek sits the stain of an old tear not yet washed off. If you were ever yourself, these woes were all for Rosaline, and are you changed? Pronounce this verdict then: women may fall when men are weak.

speaker: ROMEO
content: You often scolded me for loving Rosaline.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: For infatuation, not for loving, my pupil.

speaker: ROMEO
content: And you told me to bury love.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Not in a grave to put one love in and take another out.

speaker: ROMEO
content: I pray you, do not scold me; the one I love now returns grace for grace and love for love. The other did not.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He says that Juliet knew Romeo’s love was just memorized and recited without true understanding, like someone who can recite words but not actually spell them. Then he calls Romeo a young waverer and tells him to come along, promising to help him in one way: this marriage might turn out so happily that it transforms the hatred between their families into pure love.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo urges them to leave immediately, saying he feels a sense of urgent hurry.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar advises moving wisely and slowly, because those who run fast are prone to stumbling. This serves as a warning against Romeo’s impulsiveness.
